title: National Ecological Observatory Network
text:
Most recent forecasts
The National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) is a U.S. National Science Foundation funded project to monitor 81 ecosystems across the U.S. using standardized measurements over the next 30 years. We generate forecast for the seven lakes that are monitored by NEON. These lakes range from hot humid (Florida) to cold tundra (Alaska) environments.

Barco LakeCrampton LakeLittle Rock LakePrairie LakePrairie PotholeSuggs LakeToolik Lake





The most recent forecast is from 2022-12-16 19:00:00 (Eastern U.S. time).

title: University of Western Australia
text:
Most recent forecasts
Lake Alexandrina is located in South Australia and is monitored by the state water authority (SA Water). The forecasts are generated in collaboration with Matt Hipsey’s research group at the University of Western Australia.

Lake Alexandrina





The most recent forecast is from 2022-12-16 19:00:00 (Eastern U.S. time).

title: Lake Sunapee Protective Association
text:
Most recent forecasts
Below are forecasts for Lake Sunapee, NH. Lake Sunapee is the fifth largest lake in New Hampshire. The forecasts are for the location of the bouy that is maintained by the Lake Sunapee Protective Association.

Lake Sunapee





The most recent forecast is from 2022-12-16 19:00:00 (Eastern U.S. time).

title: Western Virginia Water Authority
text:
Most recent forecasts
Below are forecasts for three reservoirs managed by the Western Virginia Water Authority (WVWA). The WVWA is the primary supplier of drinking water to the Roanoke, VA region.

Falling Creek ReservoirBeaver Dam ReservoirCarvins Cove Reservoir

title: Home
text:
Welcome to the Forecasting Lake and Reservoir Ecosystems (FLARE) dashboard!
This page was last updated on 2022-12-17 07:22:52 (Eastern U.S. time).
This dashboard provides daily updates to visualize recent water quality forecasts generated across the world using FLARE system. FLARE iterative updates model simulations using real-time data and quantifies uncertainty in forecasts.

FLARE sites







This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation as part of awards CNS-1737424, DBI-1933102, and DBI-1933016​. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation.
